title: Under Armour lifts outlook after Q2 revenue hike
text:
Q2 profit of $15m versus $18m Revenues increase 29% to $784m Interest in fitness and athleisure speeding growth 
Under Armour booked its 21st consecutive quarter of revenue growth above 20% 
Sportswear specialist Under Armour has lifted its full-year outlook after booking its 21st consecutive quarter of revenue growth above 20%, driven by consumers ongoing interest in fitness and athleisure products. 
While revenues increased 29% to $784m from $610m in the prior year, net income slipped to US$15m for the three months to 30 June, compared with $18m in the same period last year. 
Gross margin dropped to 48.4% from 49.2%, primarily reflecting the impacts of foreign exchange rates and planned air freight expenses. 
Apparel revenues grew 23% to $515m, driven by enhanced product offerings in baselayer and training, while footwear revenues jumped 40% to $154m, due to continued product expansion across the running category. 
Accessories revenues increased 39% to $83, thanks to new introductions across the bags category. 
Direct-to-consumer revenues, which represented 32% of total revenues, were up 33% year-on-year, and international revenues surged 93%. 
"More than ever before, this year has highlighted that the right investments are key to not only driving near-term results, but building the foundation for the unlimited potential of the Under Armour brand," said chairman and CEO Kevin Plank. 
He later added: "With our Connected Fitness community now totalling more than 140 million unique registered users and adding on average more than 100,000 new athletes each day, we are pleased with our progress and believe we are still in the early stages of uncovering the potential of what the world's largest digital health and fitness community can do to build consumer engagement and drive healthier lifestyles." 
The company now expects full-year revenues to reach $3.84bn, representing growth of 25% over 2014, and above its earlier guidance of $3.78bn. Operating income is forecast to range from $405-408m, representing growth of 14-15% over 2014, and above its earlier expectations of $400-408m. 
Conlumino analyst Neil Saunders said the ongoing interest in fitness and athleisure products across the US continues to provide a "useful tailwind", which he believes is speeding Under Armourâ€™s growth. "With strong numbers also being reported from companies like Nike this trend shows no immediate signs of slowing down." 
Saunders believes Under Armour will use its Connected Fitness business, which is now one of the largest global digital fitness communities, to help launch a new range of wearable technology later in the year.
